analyzed: yoṣāyāḥ āsya padmena prāśane kriyamāṇe yathecchikī bhāṣāyāḥ anusphurtiḥ bhavati iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that when eating with the lotus of the mouth of a woman is done, the indistinctness of desired speech occurs.

original: anena vākyena śravaṇādivyavasāyarahite 'pi jane niṣprayāsenaiva tridaśānāṃ gīḥ svamukhāt prādurbhūyata ity arthaḥ // /
analyzed: anena vākyena śravaṇa ādi vyavasāya rahite jane niṣprayāsena eva tridaśānām gīḥ sva mukhāt prādurbhūyate iti arthaḥ
translated: By this sentence, the meaning is that even in a person devoid of the determination of hearing etc., the speech of the thirty gods arises from his own mouth effortlessly.

original: anyad apy utkṛṣṭataraṃ phalaviśeṣāntaraṃ svīkāramātreṇa saṃpradarśayati // /
analyzed: anyat api utkṛṣṭataram phala viśeṣa antaram svīkāra mātreṇa saṃpradarśayati
translated: He shows another even more excellent special result by mere acceptance.

original: śyāmāyā āsyasahasrapattrād anuprāśanam aparokṣānubhavena mūlaprakṛteḥ svarūpasyānudarśanam //
analyzed: śyāmāyāḥ āsya sahasrapattrāt anuprāśanam a parokṣa anubhavena mūlaprakṛteḥ svarūpasya anudarśanam  /
translated: The tasting of the thousand-petaled lotus of the mouth of the dark one is the direct experience of the nature of the primordial Prakṛti.

original: śyāmāyā āsyasahasrapattrād iti // /
analyzed: śyāmāyāḥ āsya sahasra pattrāt iti
translated: From the thousand-petaled lotus of the mouth of the dark one, etc.

original: śyāmāyāḥ kamalaprasūnāt anuprāśanaṃ pratyakṣānubhavena sākṣāt mūlaprakṛteḥ svarūpānudarśane🔽hetuḥ kāraṇam iti tayā saha saṃprāśane kriyamāṇe kṛtsnasya prapañcasya kāraṇabhūtāyāḥ
analyzed: śyāmāyāḥ kamala prasūnāt anuprāśanam pratyakṣa anubhavena sākṣāt mūlaprakṛteḥ svarūpa anudarśane  hetuḥ kāraṇam iti tayā saha saṃprāśane kriyamāṇe kṛtsnasya prapañcasya kāraṇa bhūtāyāḥ
translated: The tasting of the lotus of the dark one is the direct experience of the nature of the primordial Prakṛti by direct experience.

original: mūlaprakṛteḥ sākaṃ saṃgato bhavati // /
analyzed: mūlaprakṛteḥ sākam saṃgataḥ bhavati
translated: The cause is the reason. When the tasting is done with that, one becomes united with the primordial Prakṛti, which is the cause of the entire manifestation.🔽...

original: yad vā tatsvarūpaṃ sākṣād avyavadhānena paśyatīty arthaḥ // /
analyzed: yat vā tad svarūpam sākṣāt avyavadhānena paśyati iti arthaḥ
translated: Or the meaning is that one directly sees that nature without any obstruction.

original: anena vākyena sāyujyādikaṃ phalam api nirāyāsena prāpnotīty arthaḥ // /
analyzed: anena vākyena sāyujya ādikam phalam api nirāyāsena prāpnoti iti arthaḥ
translated: By this sentence, the meaning is that one also attains the result such as Sāyujya without effort.

original: ratikāle sīdhupānaṃ kartavyaṃ vidhibodhitam // /
analyzed: rati kāle sīdhu pānam kartavyam vidhi bodhitam
translated: The drinking of wine at the time of pleasure should be done as instructed by the rules.🔽...

original: tat purastāt kāmaśāstre proktaṃ krīḍānuvarṇanam // /
analyzed: tat purastāt kāmaśāstre proktam krīḍā anuvarṇanam
translated: That description of play has been stated earlier in the treatise on love.

original: tat sarvaṃ tu prakartavyaṃ yoṣāyāḥ sukhalabdhaye // /
analyzed: tat sarvam tu prakartavyam yoṣāyāḥ sukha labdhaye
translated: All that should be done for the pleasure of the woman.

original: svasyāpi sukhabodhāya apatyotpattihetave // /
analyzed: svasya api sukha bodhāya apatya utpatti hetave
translated: For the sake of one's own pleasure and for the begetting of offspring.

original: phaladvayaṃ sa prāpnoti prajāṃ kāmasukhaṃ tathā // /
analyzed: phala dvayam sa prāpnoti prajām kāma sukham tathā
translated: He attains both fruits, offspring and the pleasure of love.

original: urvaśīlokam āpnoti antakāle tu saḥ pumān // /
analyzed: urvaśī lokam āpnoti antakāle tu saḥ pumān
translated: At the time of death, that man attains the world of Urvashi.

original: iti śrīmahārājarṣivaryeṇa purūravasā viracitaṃ kāmijanānāṃ vinodāya rativilāsāṅgabhūtaṃ kādambarasvīkaraṇasūtraṃ savyākhyānaṃ samāptim agamat
analyzed: iti śrī mahā rājarṣi varyeṇa purūravasā viracitam kāmi janānām vinodāya rativilāsa aṅga bhūtam kādambarasvīkaraṇa sūtram sa vyākhyānam samāptim agamat
translated: Thus ends the Sutra on Accepting the Kadamba Flower, which is an auxiliary to the sport of love, composed by the illustrious great sage King Pururava for the amusement of lovers, along with its commentary.
